title: If Parents Lie To Children, They Grow Up To Become Dishonest Adults Claims A New Study
text:
If you try to instill fear in your child by lying to him/her (saying things like if you don't behave I'll call the police), you might want to stop that, as according to a research, it could be damaging for your child, cultivating selfish, scheming and rather harmful personality traits.

Representative Image: Rawpixel

The research (published in the Journal of Experimental Child Psychology) was conducted by scientists at Nayang Technological University, Singapore, where they surveyed 379 adults and asked them whether their parents lied to them when they were little and how much they lie to their parents now, along with the way faced challenges on the path to adulthood.

The research was conducted in collaboration with the University of Toronto as well as the University of California, San Diego, and China's Zhejiang Normal University.

Researchers discovered that people whose parents weren't honest with them, have difficulty in interacting with people normally, where they overstate facts and deceive listeners.

According to the lead author, Assistant Professor Setoh Peipei, "Parenting by lying can seem to save time especially when the real reasons behind why parents want children to do something is complicated to explain." He further added, "When parents tell children that 'honesty is the best policy', but display dishonesty by lying, such behaviour can send conflicting messages to their children. 'Parents' dishonesty may eventually erode trust and promote dishonesty in children.'

Representative Image: Rawpixel

She stated that one of the limitations of the study was getting teens to talk about their childhood memories -- many of which had faded with time. She further added that future investigations could help them decipher the reason why parents choose to lie in the first place.

The researcher also shares that instead of lying like this, parents could acknowledge the child's feelings and give him information by either offering choices and options or help in solving the problem.

For example, if the child is being stubborn on eating candy at home, a parent could just say that we are all out of it, instead of threatening them and instill fear.
